content.webTitle: Andrew Robb blames Turnbull and Joyce for 'toxic' relationship with China

fields.headline: Andrew Robb blames Turnbull and Joyce for 'toxic' relationship with China
fields.bodyText: The former trade minister Andrew Robb, who took an $880,000 job with a Chinese company as soon as he left parliament, has blasted his former party room colleagues and Australia’s security agencies for creating a “toxic” relationship with China. Robb confirmed he had left Landbridge, which holds the lease over the Darwin port, late last year, after a health precinct project he had been working on was rejected by Beijing. Speaking to the ABC, Robb said he blamed his former parliamentary colleagues, particularly Barnaby Joyce and Malcolm Turnbull, for souring relations between the two nations, and said Australia’s security agencies needed to prove its claims China was a threat. Robb said the Landbridge CEO had been told “in no uncertain terms by the senior officials that unfortunately the relationship between Australia and China had become so toxic that his [the health precinct proposal] would be put in the bin”. “… We had our deputy prime minister last year stand up in front of a Channel Nine TV camera and say ‘I want all Australians to know that Isis is not a security threat, China is our security threat’. That is irresponsible,” Robb told the ABC. He also claimed Australia’s security agencies needed to put up or shut up in their criticisms of China. “The evidence is not there,” he said. “We see a lot of nose-touching by the security people: ‘If you only knew what I know, you’d be horrified.’ “Well, tell us. Let us know. I was in the National Security Committee and I’ve gotta say I didn’t learn much more than I read in the papers.” But Robb seemingly saved his most scathing assessment for Turnbull’s actions in late 2017. During a particularly fraught period in Beijing-Canberra relations, which coincided with the Bennelong byelection, Turnbull delivered a quote, often, but perhaps wrongly, attributed to Chairman Mao at the founding of the People’s Republic of China in 1949, while defending Australia’s introduction of foreign interference laws. “Modern China was founded in 1949 with these words: ‘Zhongguo renmin zhanqilai’ – the Chinese people have stood up’,” Turnbull told reporters in December 2017. “It was an assertion of sovereignty, it was an assertion of pride,” he continued. “And so we say: ‘Aodaliya renmin zhanqilai – the Australian people stand up.’” Robb said it was the final straw. “… When the former prime minister [Turnbull] of Australia, in bringing in a register of people who are working for foreign companies, got up and in Mandarin said something, paraphrased that for Australia, as standing up for its freedom … they [China] were just gob-smacked and deeply offended.” Robb’s departure from parliament in 2016 and straight into a high-paying consulting gig with Landbridge, whose owner, Ye Cheng, has close ties with the ruling Chinese Communist party, raised concerns and calls for change. Robb had negotiated a free-trade agreement with Beijing while trade minister and was also vocal in support for the sale of the Darwin port, which ended with Landbridge winning a 99-year lease for the key trading stop, for $506m. In his interview with the ABC, Robb again defended taking the $880,000 consulting job with the Chinese company. “I’ve been pilloried and used and abused … [it’s] been very helpful to try and sell some security measures and things, but I understood my responsibilities as much as anyone, more than most I think,” he said. “… I’ve never spent one minute doing work in Australia, notwithstanding what you read endlessly about this being treasonous and greedy and all the rest of it.”
